posts.name: Clayton Ramsey
posts.cooked:
I emerge from the depths once more to give you a linear-traveling CAD assembly. I had originally planned to publish this at the end of summer, but life got in the way - oops.

(PhotoView 360 has been deprecated, and I don’t have a Visualize license, so no pretty renders this time. Let me know if you have a Visualize license that I can borrow :])

image 353×1417 75.7 KB Screenshot 2025-01-09 105846 309×1497 75.5 KB

image 353×1417 75.7 KB Screenshot 2025-01-09 105846 309×1497 75.5 KB

image 353×1417 75.7 KB

image 353×1417 75.7 KB

Screenshot 2025-01-09 105846 309×1497 75.5 KB

Screenshot 2025-01-09 105846 309×1497 75.5 KB

This is a differential elevator : it has two degrees of freedom (a prismatic extension and a revolute shoulder pivot) but both motors driving it are fixed at the bottom. We achieve this via a differential mechanism: the left and right sides of the carriage are held up by two independent belts, driven by independent motors. The common-mode travel of the motors controls the rotation of the shoulder, while the differential-mode travel determines the position of the elevator. This gets big savings in weight and wiring complexity at the cost of increasing the difficulty of controlling and fabricating the robot.

image 593×1516 147 KB

image 593×1516 147 KB

image 593×1516 147 KB

The entire thing is held together by one giant continuous belt run - it’s 9.5m long. To assemble this, you’d have to splice the belt from a piece of 10m stock (which does exist on the internet). I think that’s the main impracticality of the design - if building a real differential elevator, ropes might be a saner choice.

image 956×1331 190 KB

image 956×1331 190 KB

image 956×1331 190 KB

Since the shoulder pivot requires a much larger gear ratio than the elevator itself, I added an extra gear stage inside of the carriage to increase the shoulder torque.

The big orange blob is a sample hub for mounting an arm made from a 1" diameter tube. It also contains a little track for an energy chain. In-season, I would probably make a special hub for whatever arm I build, so that I can keep all the motors and high-weight parts away from the tip of the arm.

View the CAD here (native + STEP): https://grabcad.com/library/a-differential-belt-in-tube-elevator-for-frc-1 Also, check out my design calculator here: DE design calculator - Google Sheets

The assembly was designed before this year’s game, so it’s a little too tall, but it’s not much trouble to alter the height of a few parts. It’s intended for a 5-lb 12" arm, so you’d have to build a very lightweight manipulator to use it. The total weight of the assembly (according to SW) is 13 lb.

posts.name: Brett
posts.cooked: Honestly, this is the absolute coolest looking elevator ever! I would totally love to see this working in person.

posts.name: Joshua Wang
posts.cooked:
My team has used a differential elevator for the past three seasons, and one key challenge each time has been achieving satisfactory force and range of motion for the differential degree of freedom without resorting to a (nonexistent) closed belt. Our solution has been to increase the size of the differential pulley and fasten the ends of the belt or rope to it; a rope winding multiple times around a smaller pulley could also work.

Another issue to keep in mind is that moving both degrees of freedom at once is generally suboptimal. This is because the motors must run at different speeds, decreasing their total power output. The power available to the differential will also be limited by the lift’s need to counteract gravity.

posts.name: M
posts.cooked: You got your answer with FRC 1690 Orbit.

posts.name: Brett
posts.cooked: You know I saw orbit’s reveal and this was one of my first thoughts.

posts.name: Evan B
posts.cooked:
My team is doing an offseason project to build one of these, so I have a question.

How can we get a belt at a specific size while also being so long?

We got a ton of open-ended belt but it looks like splicing it is super difficult. I also can’t seem to find much online that matches what we need for our elevator.

posts.name: Eric Bergquist
posts.cooked: Given that Orbit decided to splice their belt despite the obvious drawbacks, I wouldn’t have much hope that a loop belt of this length can be sourced on an FRC budget.

posts.name: Clayton Ramsey
posts.cooked: In this design, you’re forced to splice anyway, since it’s impossible to assemble without breaking the loop on the belt. However, I think it is possible to source a 10 meter long timing belt. I unfortunately can’t find it on short notice, but I remember seeing such a belt online while I was working on this design.

posts.name: Yair Kornblau
posts.cooked:
One thing to note:

Our splice failed often, basically before each of our events (we saw it as a lucky omen - on the last practice before comp). I would not go for a belts-in-tube design simply because it makes swapping belts THAT much harder. Overall seems like a very solid design though.

posts.name: Andy Mundell
posts.cooked:
ClayTownR:

Since the shoulder pivot requires a much larger gear ratio than the elevator itself, I added an extra gear stage inside of the carriage to increase the shoulder torque.

Very cool stuff! Are there any specific calculations done to determine the effective gear ratio of the pivot? I would assume some of the torque is being used to keep the elevator up, but would it be a combination of the elevator gear ratio and the ratio on the carriage?

Is it most effective to control this type of mechanism by first moving to the proper height and THEN rotating the pivot, or can you pretty easily execute two motion profiles simultaneously?

posts.name: Eric Bergquist
posts.cooked:
suPURDUEperAndy:

Is it most effective to control this type of mechanism by first moving to the proper height and THEN rotating the pivot, or can you pretty easily execute two motion profiles simultaneously?

I believe this is pretty simple to create simultaneous motion for if you use the CTRE differential follower command.

The Follower control logic of CTRE is not working CAN

The Follower control logic of CTRE is not working CAN

link_counts.title: The Follower control logic of CTRE is not working

posts.name: Charlie shaw
posts.cooked: same here, but also on my team’s robot.

posts.name: Rod
posts.cooked:
You would need to run the numbers, but I suspect that the belt doesn’t actually need to move all that far relative to the tubes, or very far side to side.  You might be able to actually put a hard splice on one of the long runs.  Gearing the arm rotation would increase this motion, though.  Imagine a clamp a few inches long starting out most of the way up on the left hand outermost vertical run.  Going up moves the splice down.  The tricky part is that arm rotation moves it both ways Another sneaky thought is to choose things so that the arm is within a certain range of motion any time its -down-.  And maybe restrict the range when its fully up too.

I could see offsetting the belt ends on the arm and going to a dual drum/divided spool.  That would let you terminate the ends and apply tension and allow a few rotations.

posts.name: Zachary kay
posts.cooked: I wonder if you can use a v belt that’s for a mower

posts.name: Charlie shaw
posts.cooked: Could you; yes. Should you; no.

posts.name: Mike Schreiber
posts.cooked:
Does a configuration like this help you halve the belt length to a reasonable length? You can do two belts, one per side, and a ~5m continuous belt might actually exist. I’ll need to draw a FBD and think through the loads, but I think this works.

image 997×1024 58.1 KB

image 997×1024 58.1 KB

image 997×1024 58.1 KB

posts.name: Rod
posts.cooked: V-belts don’t have that synchronous thing; they are a friction drive.  The V-wedging action would only work on the normal side of the belt.  Also, you might find the fatigue life was reduced; normal V-belts don’t have fully reversed bending, but this application would.  They also don’t work with tiny pulleys like these belts do. That said, you could do a twist system like the Corvair to deal with the reversed bending thing.

posts.name: Clayton Ramsey
posts.cooked:
suPURDUEperAndy:

Very cool stuff! Are there any specific calculations done to determine the effective gear ratio of the pivot? I would assume some of the torque is being used to keep the elevator up, but would it be a combination of the elevator gear ratio and the ratio on the carriage?

Yep! My original calc sheet (same as the one in the OP) has calculations for the shoulder pivot assuming the elevator is fixed in space. The effective gear ratio is 36:1, which is pretty low by pivot standards, but acceptable with a very light end-effector. When 1690 implemented their differential elevator, they added an extra gear stage in the carriage to account for their longer arm and higher-weight game pieces.

To calculate the holding current, you have to add the load from both mechanisms, so IIRC the total current is just the sum of each current (would need to do actual calcs to verify but this is a good first approximation). In this design the holding current is about 12A per motor.

suPURDUEperAndy:

Is it most effective to control this type of mechanism by first moving to the proper height and THEN rotating the pivot, or can you pretty easily execute two motion profiles simultaneously?

Depends on how good you are at controls ;P.

Mike_Schreiber:

Does a configuration like this help you halve the belt length to a reasonable length? You can do two belts, one per side, and a ~5m continuous belt might actually exist. I’ll need to draw a FBD and think through the loads, but I think this works.

I think this would work! At the very least, it checks out in the brain simulator.

Also, if I were building this robot for realsies, I would probably be going up to a larger tooth size + wider belt anyway, so longer belts would be easier to source. However, with a continuous belt, you would have to take the belts out of the tubes to make assembly physically possible (or alternately, make the frame out of C-channels instead of tubes).

posts.name: Mike Schreiber
posts.cooked:
ClayTownR:

However, with a continuous belt, you would have to take the belts out of the tubes to make assembly physically possible (or alternately, make the frame out of C-channels instead of tubes).

You want to be able to assemble it?! Solid point.

C Channel elevators are a whole different problem to deal with. Not sure if that’s better or worse than dealing with a belt seam.

ClayTownR:

larger tooth size + wider belt

This is pretty hard unless you go with a tube bigger than 2x1. We ran 3/4” round tube as our idler this year on our 5mm pitch x 15mm wide belt in tube elevator. You can’t fit a larger tube in a 2x1 without increasing the distance between the tubes (which has bearing block implications) and I would not want to use a smaller diameter on a 5mm pitch belt. A larger pitch would have a larger minimum bend radius. Using 2 x 2 opens up a lot of new options though.

posts.name: Skye Leake
posts.cooked:
As long as you have spools that guarantee a consistent diameter (to avoid creating unwanted differential movement) a capstan may be a sleek solution here as well.

You would likely need some sort of tensioner idler or inline spring to take up any slack, but otherwise it could be very compact, eliminating the green and blue idlers in your schematic.
